content.text:
Suppose you discovered a mutant yeast whose glycolytic pathway was shorter because of the presence of a new enzyme catalyzing the reaction <image 1> Would shortening the glycolytic pathway in this way benefit the cell?

A. Yes.
B. No.
C. Not sure.

To determine whether shortening the glycolytic pathway would benefit the cell, we need to consider the role of the reaction shown in the image and its implications for the overall glycolytic process.

The reaction shown is:
\[ \text{Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate} + \text{H}_2\text{O} \rightarrow \text{3-phosphoglycerate} + \text{NADH} + \text{H}^+ \]

This reaction is part of the glycolytic pathway and involves the conversion of glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate to 3-phosphoglycerate, with the production of NADH and H⁺. NADH is an important electron carrier that plays a crucial role in cellular respiration, contributing to the generation of ATP.

If a new enzyme were to catalyze this reaction more efficiently or if the pathway were shortened in such a way that this step occurred more frequently, it could potentially lead to increased production of NADH. This increased production of NADH could enhance the efficiency of cellular respiration and ATP production, which would be beneficial to the cell.

Therefore, shortening the glycolytic pathway in this way would likely benefit the cell.

The correct answer is:
A. Yes.
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
